definition: Functional domain covering financial privacy practices, consumer information collection and disclosure, privacy notices, opt-out rights, and compliance with GLBA Financial Privacy Rule (Regulation P) requirements.
official_description: Privacy domain encompasses all activities related to protecting consumer choice and transparency regarding nonpublic personal information handling. Includes privacy notice development and distribution, opt-out mechanism implementation, information sharing governance with affiliates and non-affiliated third parties, consumer rights management, privacy policy documentation, and coordination with marketing and business development on permissible information uses. Overseen by Privacy Officer or Chief Privacy Officer.
applicable_to: Financial institutions collecting, using, or sharing consumer NPI; Privacy Officers; Compliance teams; Marketing departments; Legal departments
organization_owner: Institution-level ownership; Typically Privacy Officer or Chief Privacy Officer
version: GLBA Title V Subtitle A; Regulation P
key_features: Privacy notice management (initial and annual); Opt-out program administration; Consumer rights request handling; Information sharing governance; Affiliate and third-party sharing controls; Privacy policy development and updates; Consumer complaint management; Privacy training and awareness; Regulatory examination preparation; Model privacy form usage; FAST Act annual notice exemption eligibility assessment

definition: Functional domain covering information security safeguards, cybersecurity controls, risk management, technical protections, and compliance with GLBA Safeguards Rule requirements for protecting customer information confidentiality, integrity, and availability.
official_description: Security domain encompasses comprehensive information security program including risk assessment, safeguard implementation (administrative, technical, physical), access controls, encryption, authentication, vulnerability management, penetration testing, security monitoring, incident detection and response, disaster recovery, business continuity, and continuous security improvement. Managed by Security Officer, CISO, or Qualified Individual under Safeguards Rule. Coordinates across IT, operations, compliance, and business units.
applicable_to: All financial institutions; Security Officers; CISOs; IT security teams; IT operations; System administrators; Compliance teams
organization_owner: Institution-level ownership; Typically CISO, Security Officer, or Qualified Individual
key_features: Information security program development and maintenance; Risk assessment (periodic written); Administrative safeguards (policies, procedures, access controls, training); Technical safeguards (encryption, MFA, firewalls, intrusion detection, secure development); Physical safeguards (facility access, environmental controls, media protection); Continuous monitoring and testing; Vulnerability assessments (biannual/quarterly); Penetration testing (annual); Security awareness training; Incident response; Vendor security oversight; Change management; Patch management; Audit logging; Annual board reporting

definition: Functional domain focused on preventing fraudulent acquisition of customer information through false pretenses, social engineering, deception, or impersonation, implementing identity verification, employee training, and detection mechanisms.
official_description: Pretexting prevention domain encompasses all measures to prevent unauthorized information disclosure through social engineering attacks. Includes identity verification procedure development and enforcement, employee training on pretexting recognition, multi-factor authentication for information requests, suspicious request detection and escalation, data shielding practices (masking sensitive information), access restriction enforcement, monitoring for unusual information access patterns, investigation of suspected incidents, and coordination with fraud prevention teams. Critical for call centers, customer service, account servicing, and any staff handling customer inquiries.
applicable_to: All financial institution employees; Customer-facing staff; Call centers; Account servicing; Customer support; Help desks; Compliance and security teams
organization_owner: Institution-level; Often joint responsibility of Security, Compliance, and Operations
key_features: Identity verification procedures (knowledge-based, multi-factor); Employee training on pretexting tactics and social engineering; Suspicious request identification and escalation; Secondary verification for high-risk requests; Data shielding and masking procedures; Access restrictions and need-to-know controls; Monitoring and audit logging of information access; Red flag detection; Investigation procedures for suspected pretexting; Caller authentication protocols; Script development for consistent responses; Regular training simulations and testing; Coordination with security and fraud teams

definition: Functional domain covering third-party service provider risk management, vendor due diligence, contract management, ongoing vendor oversight, and compliance with GLBA requirements for service providers with customer information access.
official_description: Vendor management domain encompasses entire third-party lifecycle: vendor identification and inventory, pre-engagement due diligence and security assessment, risk tiering and classification, contract negotiation including security requirements, onboarding and access provisioning, ongoing monitoring and periodic assessments, vendor audit and report review (SOC 2, ISO 27001, penetration tests), compliance tracking, remediation management, contract renewal assessment, secure offboarding and access termination. Ensures vendors implement GLBA-equivalent safeguards and maintain chain of custody for customer information including sub-vendors. Coordinated across procurement, legal, IT, security, and compliance.
applicable_to: All financial institutions engaging third-party service providers; Procurement teams; Legal; IT; Security; Compliance; Vendor Risk Management teams
organization_owner: Institution-level; Often Vendor Risk Manager, Third-Party Risk Management team, or shared across Procurement, Security, and Compliance
status: Active domain with increasing regulatory focus
key_features: Vendor inventory and classification; Pre-engagement due diligence and security assessment; Risk-based tiering (critical, high, medium, low); Service provider agreement development with mandatory security clauses; Contract requirements: GLBA safeguards, NPI use restrictions, breach notification, audit rights, sub-vendor management; Ongoing monitoring and annual assessments; Vendor security report review; Compliance tracking and scorecard management; Remediation enforcement; Vendor access controls and monitoring; Secure vendor offboarding; Sub-vendor oversight; Centralized vendor management platform; Continuous monitoring tools

definition: Functional domain covering security incident detection, investigation, containment, notification to regulators and consumers, recovery, and post-incident improvement in accordance with GLBA breach notification requirements.
official_description: Breach notification domain encompasses incident lifecycle from detection through lessons learned: security event monitoring and detection, incident classification and severity assessment, containment and eradication, forensic investigation and evidence preservation, internal notification and escalation, regulatory notification (FTC within 30 days for 500+ individuals), consumer notification under state laws, law enforcement coordination, identity protection service offers to affected consumers, recovery and remediation, root cause analysis, corrective action implementation, and post-incident review. Requires coordination across security, legal, compliance, communications, customer service, and executive leadership. 24/7 incident response capability essential.
applicable_to: All financial institutions; Incident response teams; Security operations centers; Legal; Compliance; Communications/PR; Customer service; Executive management
organization_owner: Institution-level; Often Security Operations Center (SOC), Incident Response Team, CISO, with executive and legal oversight
version: GLBA Safeguards Rule 16 CFR 314.4(h) and 314.5; State breach notification laws
status: Active domain requiring 24/7 readiness; Federal notification effective May 13, 2024
key_features: Incident detection and monitoring; Incident classification (notification event determination); Containment and eradication procedures; Forensic investigation and evidence preservation; Breach scope and impact assessment; Internal notification protocols; FTC notification within 30 days (if 500+ affected); State consumer notification compliance; Law enforcement coordination and reporting; News media notification (if 500+ in jurisdiction); Identity protection service offerings; Customer communication and support; Recovery and remediation; Root cause analysis; Corrective action plans; Post-incident review; Incident documentation and record retention; Breach notification tracking; Regular incident response plan testing

definition: Functional domain covering GLBA regulatory compliance management, policy development, examination preparation, audit coordination, board reporting, training program management, and compliance monitoring across all GLBA requirements.
official_description: Compliance and governance domain encompasses enterprise-wide GLBA compliance program: compliance program development and maintenance, policy and procedure documentation, regulatory examination preparation and coordination, internal and external audit support, board and senior management reporting, compliance training program management, regulatory change monitoring and impact assessment, compliance risk assessment, issue tracking and remediation, regulatory relationship management with FTC and other agencies, complaint management and investigation, compliance documentation and record retention, and cross-functional compliance coordination. Ensures all GLBA domains (privacy, security, pretexting prevention) operate effectively and meet regulatory requirements.
applicable_to: All financial institutions; Compliance officers; Chief Compliance Officers; Legal; Audit; Board of Directors; Senior management; All business units
organization_owner: Institution-level; Typically Chief Compliance Officer or VP of Compliance
key_features: Compliance program development and oversight; GLBA policy and procedure documentation; Regulatory examination preparation (FTC, banking regulators); Internal audit coordination; External audit and third-party assessment coordination; Board reporting (at least annually); Senior management reporting; Compliance risk assessment; Issue and findings tracking and remediation; Regulatory change monitoring; Training program management (privacy, security, pretexting); Compliance testing and monitoring; Regulatory relationship management; Consumer complaint investigation and reporting; Compliance documentation and recordkeeping; Enforcement action response; Corrective action plan development and tracking; Cross-functional compliance coordination
